name: Capitol News Illinois
title: Legislature passes ‘medical aid in dying’ bill that governor says he will review
description: The measure passed with the minimum votes needed in the Senate.

name: Missouri Independent
title: Missouri voters approve four-day school week in two districts, showing rising support
description: When the Independence School District announced it was switching to a four-day week during the 2023-24 school year, it drew questions from local families and statewide officials. Parents wondered what kind of child care they would have on days without classroom instruction. And lawmakers debated whether the state needed to intervene. Ultimately, Missouri’s G[...]
text:
On Tuesday, voters in two Missouri towns approved a four-day school week. Both districts had already been operating on the schedule but required voter approval to continue (Annelise Hanshaw/Missouri Independent).When the Independence School District announced it was switching to a four-day week during the 2023-24 school year, it drew questions from local families and statewide officials.
Parents wondered what kind of child care they would have on days without classroom instruction. And lawmakers debated whether the state needed to intervene.
Ultimately, Missouri’s General Assembly passed a law requiring a vote for non–rural school districts to authorize a four-day week.
On Tuesday, the Independence and Hallsville school districts became the first large districts to receive the approval of voters to continue with four-day weeks.
“I knew that the majority of our community supported it,” Hallsville Superintendent Tyler Walker told The Independent. “I was a little bit surprised to see how much support it was.”
In Hallsville, residents had two questions on the ballot related to the school district. One asked about the four-day week and the other was a bond measure previously passed in April but not confirmed by the State Auditor.
Four-day school week faces scrutiny from Missouri legislature, state education board

The election drew 25% of registered voters, according to the Boone County Clerk, and 75% of those voted in favor of the four-day school week. The vote authorizes the schedule for the next 10 years, when then the district will have to hold another special election.
Walker didn’t think the margin would be that wide. Earlier surveys from the district’s 2022 adoption of the schedule put approval at around 60%.
He believes that the district’s growing success on standardized tests and other publicly available metrics have given families confidence that the four-day week isn’t such a bad thing.
“Our community has grown to appreciate the four day week more after experiencing it for a few years,” he said.
Todd Fuller, director of communications for the Missouri State Teachers Association, told The Independent that voters in districts who have already been operating in a four-day week like Independence and Hallsville have an idea of how it works for their students. The state law, passed in 2024, will require a vote prior to the schedule’s adoption for those who do not already adopt the abbreviated week.
“Anyone who’s a constituent of the district has had time to digest this process, and they’ve been able to decide over a two-year period whether it’s been beneficial or not beneficial for their kids,” Fuller said. “So if they are expressing that feeling with their vote, then we’re going to have a pretty good understanding of what they really want.”
The association doesn’t have an official stance on the four-day week. But Fuller said the teachers it represents have been pleased with the schedule.
Jorjana Pohlman, president of Independence’s branch of the Missouri National Education Association, told The Independent that the overall sentiment is positive from the district’s educators.
Mondays out of the classroom have become a good time for teachers to have doctor’s appointments, spend time with their families and plan for the week ahead, she said.
“In the beginning, it was fear of the unknown for families as well as teachers,” she said. “A lot of teachers had the attitude of, ‘Let’s try it.’ They, I think overall, felt it was a positive thing.”
A study by Missouri State University researchers looked at recent applicants to teaching positions in Independence, finding that the four-day week was a key part of the district’s recruitment.
In particular, 63% of applicants rated the four-day schedule as a top-three reason for applying, and 27% said it was their top priority.
The study also looked at the value of the four-day week for applicants, asking how much they would sacrifice in salary to work at a district with the schedule. On average, applicants were willing to sacrifice $2267 annually for the four-day week.
Walker said the schedule has also improved recruitment in Hallsville, with a dramatic uptick in veteran teachers applying to positions.
With teachers coming to Independence schools particularly for their schedule, some worried that returning to a five-day week would have large consequences for staffing. But Pohlman said a survey showed that the loss of educators is less than many would think.
“The educators, they care deeply about their students, and they want what’s best for students and for the community, whether it’s four day week or five day week,” she said. “They are still going to be committed.”
Almost a third of Missouri districts have adopted a four-day week, with around 91% of those districts in rural settings. Only districts in cities with at least 30,000 residents, or those located in Jackson, Clay, St. Louis, Jefferson and St. Charles counties, must call for a vote before moving to a four-day week.

name: Maine Morning Star
title: Augusta voters reject school board candidate that sought to overturn transgender protections
description: With a third of Augusta school board seats on the ballot Tuesday, city residents backed all three candidates that were supported by the Maine Democratic Party, rejecting at least one challenger who campaigned on rolling back the district’s inclusive transgender policy. The school board has made recent headlines for increasingly tense debates over the policy,[...]
text:
The polls at the Woodfords Club in Portland on Election Day, Nov. 4, 2025. (Photo by Jim Neuger/ Maine Morning Star)With a third of Augusta school board seats on the ballot Tuesday, city residents backed all three candidates that were supported by the Maine Democratic Party, rejecting at least one challenger who campaigned on rolling back the district’s inclusive transgender policy.
The school board has made recent headlines for increasingly tense debates over the policy, which upholds students’ right to access teams and school facilities aligning with their gender identity, as Maine law requires. For example, earlier this month, three attendees stripped off their clothes during a public meeting to make a statement about what they described as the discomfort of cisgender students when asked to share spaces with trans students. 
The school board election was seen by some as a popular referendum on the current policy. Earlier this year, several bills aiming to rescind protections for trans students failed passage in the Maine Legislature, but local districts have been considering changing their rules, and at least eight already have.
Maine towns to weigh in on minimum wage, child care, and public education battles

At-large incumbent Rita Pello defeated challenger Kelly Smith with over 58% of the vote. Smith told the Kennebec Journal ahead of the election that one of her priorities is to “uphold Title IX while protecting fairness in female sports.” 
The Trump administration has claimed that including transgender girls’ in girls sports violates federal anti-discrimination law, though that argument has not been backed by the courts.
In a Facebook post after the results were announced, Pello said she’s grateful for “those in our community that quietly voted for students’ and our schools’ best interests.”
In the open race for Ward 4, Bobby-Jo Bechard defeated Jaden Siracusa and William Clardy, who in a previous bid for Maine Legislature said if elected he would “question an office under the Attorney General which has been actively pushing gender politics into pre-pubescent grade levels.”
Bechard said ahead of the vote, “I think it’s important for the community to know that every student should feel seen, supported and inspired, no matter their background or circumstances and that’s really important to me.” 
Samuel Baker ran unopposed for Ward 1, defeating declared write-in John Reny.
Katrina Ray-Saulis, an Augusta resident who works in education, said the results show that city residents “are not interested in continuing the unnecessary drama that’s been happening at our school board and city council meetings.”
Democrats did well nationally in Tuesday’s election. There were no statewide races but Maine voters rejected a referendum that sought to require voter identification and limit absentee voting while backing an initiative to implement an additional gun safety measure known as a red flag law. 
SUPPORT: YOU MAKE OUR WORK POSSIBLE

name: Minnesota Reformer
title: Jacob Frey wins third term as Minneapolis mayor
description: Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey won a third term on Wednesday, overcoming a tough challenge from three rivals working together as a team to topple him. Frey had a 10-point lead over Sen. Omar Fateh, his strongest challenger, on Tuesday evening, and he received 50% of the votes after first- and second-choice votes were tallied. Progressives […]
text:
Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey signs an ordinance loosening regulatory requirements for developers converting office space into housing on Sept. 24, 2024. Photo by Madison McVan/Minnesota Reformer. Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey won a third term on Wednesday, overcoming a tough challenge from three rivals working together as a team to topple him.
Frey had a 10-point lead over Sen. Omar Fateh, his strongest challenger, on Tuesday evening, and he received 50% of the votes after first- and second-choice votes were tallied.
Progressives and democratic socialists in Minnesota’s largest city again failed to out-rank Frey. With the financial help of city business interests, Frey convinced enough voters that Minneapolis’ falling crime rates and relatively modest rent increases compared to other large cities earned him a third term.
Frey thanked his supporters in a statement Wednesday.
“Minneapolis is a great city rising, and our future is bright,” Frey said. “From right now through my final seconds as mayor, I will work tirelessly to make our great city a place where everyone, regardless of who you are or where you come from, can build a brilliant life in an affordable home and a safe neighborhood.”
Fateh will return to the Minnesota Senate with an even higher profile, continuing a rapid ascent. He moved to Minnesota a decade ago and then scored an upset victory over a prominent state senator in 2020. His campaign received national media coverage and he earned the moniker “The Mamdani of Minneapolis,” a reference to the democratic socialist candidate for mayor of New York City. Mamdani won his election Tuesday.
In a statement, Fateh said he was proud of his campaign even though it was unable to prevail over big-money political action committees and wealthy donors.
“They may have won this race, but we have changed the narrative about what kind of city Minneapolis can be. Because now, truly affordable housing, workers’ rights, and public safety rooted in care are no longer side conversations; they are at the center of the narrative,” Fateh said.
Fateh’s loss signals that Minneapolis voters weren’t ready to back his democratic socialist agenda, which included a city income tax and rent control. He also wouldn’t commit to reappointing Minneapolis Chief Brian O’Hara. During his 2020 Senate campaign, he expressed support for defunding police, and he supported a failed 2021 ballot initiative to dismantle the police department and reconstitute it under the control of the City Council. This year, he signed a petition that called for Minneapolis police officers to arrest masked federal agents.
In Dinkytown, University of Minnesota Junior Bailey Taylor said Tuesday that Fateh’s past support for defunding the police was a reason he ranked Frey first.
“I don’t agree with defunding the police because that is a bit silly, especially in a city like this,” Taylor said.
Frey’s win means he will likely continue to butt heads with a City Council that is controlled by a progressive bloc. A big money coalition was unable to dislodge several Minneapolis progressives from the council. Since progressives gained control of the council two years ago, Frey has vetoed many of their proposals, including a carbon emissions fee and minimum pay rates for Uber and Lyft drivers, though the latter eventually became law after the Legislature took it up.
In addition to an adversarial council, Frey confronts a city in transition and still recovering from the pandemic, which has eroded commercial property values and pushed property taxes higher for homeowners. 
On the campaign trail, mayoral candidates DeWayne Davis, Jazz Hampton and Fateh formed an alliance, creating a united opposition to the incumbent mayor and telling voters to not rank Frey.

name: Nevada Current
title: Partial SNAP benefits delivered in Nevada
description: The Nevada Division of Social Services on Wednesday delivered approximately $29 million in food assistance benefits to the EBT cards of over 196,000 households. The amount represents roughly a third of the $90 million the federal government normally provides Nevadans each month through its Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, better known as SNAP. The[...]
text:
A shopper who receives SNAP benefits slides an EBT card at a checkout counter in a grocery store in December 2024. (Photo by U.S. Department of Agriculture)The Nevada Division of Social Services on Wednesday delivered approximately $29 million in food assistance benefits to the EBT cards of over 196,000 households.
The amount represents roughly a third of the $90 million the federal government normally provides Nevadans each month through its Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, better known as SNAP. The distribution comes after two federal judges ordered the Trump administration to use existing emergency reserves to partially pay out November benefits, which were supposed to start going out on Saturday.
A state administrator, in an email obtained by the Nevada Current, confirmed the distributions were made early Wednesday. She said some SNAP recipients won’t receive any benefits and many will receive less than 50% of what they are approved for. The distribution followed partial payment guidance from the USDA.
The state is expected to formally announce the distribution of the payments today.
In a statement, Retail Association of Nevada President Bryan Wachter said his organization confirmed SNAP funds have been successfully loaded onto EBT cards: “This is welcome news for thousands of Nevada families and for the retailers who help ensure access to food and essential goods every day.”
Wachter added that the partial payments will only provide “short-term relief.”
“Nevada families still face uncertainty about the remainder of November’s benefits,” he added. “We appreciate Governor (Joe) Lombardo and Majority Leader (Nicole) Cannizzaro for recognizing the urgency of this issue and for their willingness to explore state-level solutions during the upcoming special session.”
Cannizzaro and the Nevada Senate Democratic caucus on Tuesday announced that if a special legislative session is called later this month, as expected, they plan to introduce legislation to establish an emergency cash assistance program to act as a substitute for the lapsed SNAP benefits.
This is a developing story and will be updated.

name: Maryland Matters
title: Pinsky steps down from Maryland Energy Administration, ends 39 years in state service
description: Maryland Energy Administrator Director Paul Pinsky, who went from ideologically out-of-step back bencher to architect of major legislation, and who now is a key member of Gov. Wes Moore’s administration, will end his 39 years of state service this month.
text:
Paul G. Pinsky, director of the Maryland Energy Administration, served seven terms in the Senate and two terms in the House of Delegates. (Photo by Bryan P. Sears/Maryland Mattera)Paul Pinsky, who went from a back bencher in the General Assembly, out of step ideologically with most of his colleagues, to a major architect of consequential legislation, and who now is a key member of Gov. Wes Moore’s administration, will end his 39 years of state service later this month.
Pinsky, 75, informed his staff Wednesday morning that he is stepping down as director of the Maryland Energy Administration, a job he has held since 2023 after three dozen years in the legislature.
In an interview, Pinsky noted that most of his contemporaries have retired from full-time work – and said there’s much he wants to do in the years ahead beyond serving in public office.
“I’m the last person standing,” he said. “I do this with mixed emotions. I’m still having fun. I think I’m a good leader. But I don’t want to drop dead in a year without being able to do X, Y and Z.”
Even at the start of his political career, Pinsky called himself a progressive, when few Maryland Democrats would, only to see the party move gradually in his direction. In the years ahead he hopes to impart wisdom he’s gained from his experiences as a liberal leader in a state whose political establishment is centrist and often resistant to change.
“I want to do some writing about the lessons I’ve learned over the years, particularly for younger activists who want to run for state or local offices,” he said.
Pinsky has at times been called “the Bernie Sanders of Maryland,” and their careers have dovetailed to an extent. Pinsky said that, like Sanders, his “mantra” has been “putting people’s needs ahead of corporate greed.”
Drawing on his skills as a longtime political organizer, Pinsky has co-authored some of the most significant legislation in recent Maryland history, including the Blueprint for Maryland’s Future education reform plan and the Climate Solutions Now law that sets aggressive climate mandates for the state. Since joining the Moore administration, Pinsky has been an integral part of the state’s efforts to expand its clean energy portfolio.
Paul Pinsky talks to former Gov. Parris Glendening before the start of the 2025 State of the State. (Photo by Bryan P. Sears/Maryland Matters.)
But he was a political outlier when he was elected in 1986 to represent Prince George’s County’s District 22 in the House of Delegates, far to the left of his Democratic colleagues and party leaders. He teamed up with a fellow freshman, Brian Frosh (D-Montgomery), who went on to become state attorney general, and later with another young lawmaker, Chris Van Hollen (D-Montgomery), now Maryland’s senior U.S. senator, to form a liberal “Three Musketeers” in the legislature.
They were often at odds with the House speaker, Clay Mitchell, a conservative Democrat from the Eastern Shore. Pinsky shakes his head thinking about those days, recalling being on the losing end of several 131-10 votes.
The longtime state Senate president, Thomas V. Mike Miller Jr. (D), a fellow Prince Georgian, sought unsuccessfully to keep Pinsky from moving up to the Senate in 1994. But Pinsky persevered, advancing slowly but surely into Senate leadership – and in 2019, Miller would hand Pinsky the gavel to the powerful Senate Education, Health and Environmental Affairs Committee.
Miller, who died in 2021, eventually found his colleague to be frank and reliable – one of the most dependable members of the Senate.
“He’s come a long way,” Miller said in a 2019 interview. “We still disagree on a lot of personal views, but I trust him implicitly. He’s an honest man.”
Pinsky grew up in the New Jersey suburbs of Philadelphia and came to Washington, D.C., in 1968 to attend George Washington University. At GW, he participated in multiple student protests, falling in with a crowd of left-wing activists who became lifelong friends.
From 1976 to 1995, Pinsky was a history teacher for the Prince George’s County Public Schools – and learned the vagaries of local politics by spending four years as president of the county teachers’ union. While teaching and coaching basketball at Fairmont Heights High School, Pinsky met his future wife, Joan Rothgeb, a fellow teacher who later became an administrator in the school district – and was also a scholastic basketball coach. Pinsky later became an organizer with the Montgomery County teachers’ union.
By his own account, Pinsky often found himself on the fringes of the political debate in his early years in Annapolis, focusing on things like predatory corporate practices and whether Maryland National Guard troops should be deployed to war-torn Central America.
Maryland Energy Administration Director Paul Pinsky speaks about the state’s climate change goals as Gov. Wes Moore (D) looks on in 2024. (Photo by Bryan P. Sears/Maryland Matters)
In 1990, after Sanders, the mayor of Burlington, Vermont, was elected to Congress, Pinsky was one of a handful of Washington, D.C.-area progressives asked to organize a “Welcome to D.C.” event for Sanders. It drew 800 supporters to Eastern Market, including the Rev. Jesse Jackson and current and former members of Congress. Years later, in 2016, Pinsky was an elected delegate for Sanders’ presidential campaign at the Democratic National Convention.
In 1994, Pinsky prepared to challenge his district’s incumbent senator, Thomas P. O’Reilly, the chair of the Finance Committee, in the Democratic primary. Miller, Pinsky recalled, threatened to spend $100,000 to defeat him.
At a bullroast for U.S. Rep. Steny Hoyer (D-5th) that year, Pinsky confronted Miller, who had asked him how he was doing.
“I’d be better, Mike,” Pinsky replied, “if you’d stay the hell out of my race.”
Miller eventually backed off; O’Reilly wound up resigning before the end of his term to join the State Workers Compensation Commission, and Pinsky was appointed to replace him. He won a full term that fall – and Van Hollen and Frosh joined him in moving up to the Senate.
In their first Senate term, the three lawmakers and several of their colleagues sought to derail a deal to bring two professional football stadiums to Maryland – Pinsky arguing at the time that taxpayers shouldn’t subsidize “pleasure palaces for plutocrats.”
They fell short, but the vote was by no means a sure thing, and Pinsky said he quickly saw the advantages of being in the Senate.
“The Senate is much more fun, when you’re one of 47 [members], when they need 24 votes to pass things,” he observed. “It’s harder for you to be marginalized.”
Pinsky, Van Hollen and Frosh remain good friends, and at the time, Pinsky said, he felt exhilarated being able to collaborate with them. “It made it easier and more fun to strategize.” Van Hollen has called Pinsky “a kindred spirit.”
Pinsky said the smaller size of the chamber also enabled him to forge personal relationships with colleagues he wasn’t in sync with ideologically – including Miller.
SUPPORT: YOU MAKE OUR WORK POSSIBLE
In the Senate, Pinsky focused mostly on education, the environment, and political reform, notching some victories and some defeats. When Miller made Frosh, the Senate’s leading environmentalist, chair of the Judicial Proceedings Committee in 2003, Pinsky knew he had to pick up the mantle.
“I was like, what?” Pinsky recalled. “You’re it. It was a weight on me, frankly. I felt a duty, an obligation to do more on the environment.”
In 2006, he authored the Healthy Air Act, which imposed strict emissions controls on Maryland power plants and paved the way for the state to join the multi-state Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative, which sells carbon credits to polluters. The revenues are largely used to fund clean energy.
Pinsky also passed a bill making it easier for Maryland teachers to receive national board certification.
He gained clout over the years through his seniority, at the same time his relationship with Miller grew closer. Pinsky said he and Miller would run into each other at University of Maryland basketball games, and would make time to chat. Pinsky’s wife was diagnosed with cancer several years ago (she died in 2020, at the age of 63); Miller’s cancer diagnosis also created a bond between them.
“Over the years, Mike softened, I softened,” Pinsky reflected. “You came together. With Mike, you always knew where you stood.”
In 2015, Miller appointed Pinsky vice chair of the Education, Health and Environmental Affairs Committee, which had a broad portfolio, and four years later, after the committee chair, Sen. Joan Carter Conway (D-Baltimore City), lost her reelection bid, he handed Pinsky the gavel.
The committee did a lot of heavy lifting during Pinsky’s tenure, passing the Blueprint for Maryland’s Future, which Pinsky had spent years crafting with fellow lawmakers, educators, business and civic leaders, and developing the state’s principal climate law.
Pinsky in his final years in the legislature also passed a measure making community college free for most Marylanders, expanded Miller’s Chesapeake Bay Conservation Corps to become a climate corps, and shepherded through a bill requiring Maryland to plant 5 million new trees. He also led the legislative effort to roll back then-Gov. Larry Hogan’s (R) edict that all school systems should delay the opening of the school year until after Labor Day – creating controversy by comparing Hogan to Southern state governors in the 1950s and ‘60s who stood in the doorways of schools to prevent Black students from entering.
Sen. Paul G. Pinsky (D-Prince George’s) works on the Senate floor in 2020. (File photo by Danielle E. Gaines/Maryland Matters)
Pinsky said there was no single “Aha!” moment that made him think he had arrived as a serious policymaker after years as a bombthrower.
“It was a gradual transition,” he said, adding, “I never not wanted to be a bombthrower. I always wanted to put people ahead of corporate interests.”
But Pinsky marveled thinking about a time, when he was the committee chair, that a highly-compensated utility executive sat in his office, pressing his case for an initiative that Pinsky opposed.
“I thought to myself, what are you doing here?” he recalled. “How did I get here?”
Pinsky credited the activists he worked with on several issues to help him achieve his legislative successes. “Half my time is spent mobilizing with the base, because they’re going to make my life easy,” he said.
But Pinsky can still tally his legislative losses. He tried for years to bring “combined reporting” to Maryland – where related corporations are treated as single entities for tax purposes, a provision more than 20 other states have. Pinsky remains frustrated that lawmakers have been so reluctant to embrace this reform, which would provide substantial additional revenues.
Pinsky unsuccessfully fought legislation that gives gas companies subsidies from ratepayers to build infrastructure. His bills to ban candy and soda and corporate advertising from public schools failed. Political reform measures – including public financing for legislative campaigns – stalled.
“You have a progressive agenda, you get a few things done, but you also encounter roadblocks,” Pinsky said. “I was hoping some of the things I was talking about would become more mainstream.”
When Miller decided to step down as Senate president in 2019 after 33 years, Pinsky was among a handful of Democrats who kicked the tires on a possible bid to replace him, but eventually abandoned the idea. Baltimore City Sen. Bill Ferguson eventually won Democratic Caucus support unanimously to succeed Miller.



Need to get in touch?
Have a news tip?


CONTACT US



	Shortly after Moore was elected governor in 2022, he turned to Pinsky to head the Maryland Energy Administration. Pinsky, who had spent the past year shepherding the climate bill to final passage – and winning an eighth Senate term – was ready for a new challenge. But he also conceded that his desire to “push the envelope” during the Climate Solutions Now debate “created some tensions in the legislature,” which made it a good time to move on.
The MEA director’s role varies from administration to administration. Under Hogan, the MEA became a sleepy agency that shed staff, moved from downtown Annapolis to South Baltimore, and mainly dispensed modest clean energy grants.
Under Moore and Pinsky, the MEA is growing and has played a more central role in the administration’s clean energy and climate strategy.
Just last week, the two announced a $17 million grant program to expand community solar energy use in the state. Although there is an undeniable environmental benefit, the leaders cast the program as a cost-saving measure for certain ratepayers.
“The reason we are so focused on the issue of energy affordability is because we hear from our constituents about it every day,” Moore said. “That’s why we’re taking this important step forward to make energy more sustainable and bring prices down in communities across the state.”
Pinsky last week also headlined a news conference at a union hall in Baltimore, with Van Hollen and environmental leaders, reiterating the state’s commitment to building offshore wind energy projects despite the Trump administration’s opposition.
Pinsky admitted that when he was invited to lead the agency, he didn’t know much about energy policy, despite his years pushing environmental initiatives. But he quickly came to see that energy and climate are inextricably linked, and he has been happy in his role – offering effusive praise for the staff at MEA.
“I’m lucky in getting some pretty smart people around me, who make me look good,” he said. So many staffers, Pinsky said, believe in the agency’s mission, “which is so damn cool.”
But that will soon come to an end. Pinsky has no immediate plans – other than some household chores and spending a week in Belize with his adult daughters, who both live in Washington, D.C. (given his family’s progressive leanings, one daughter once asked him if it would be OK if she took a job in the private sector, Pinsky recalled with a laugh).
In his heart, Pinsky is still a protestor and an organizer – he attended two different “No Kings” rallies in his neighborhood in October. And that will continue even when he’s out of state government.
“You leave whatever mark you can leave,” he said.

name: Indiana Capital Chronicle
title: 3,000 children repeating third grade under new Indiana literacy requirement
description: About 3,000 Indiana students are repeating third grade this school year for not meeting the state’s reading proficiency standards.
text:
Anna Shults, the chief academic officer for the Indiana Department of Education, reviews new retention data at a board meeting Nov. 5, 2025. (Screenshot from meeting)About 3,000 Indiana students are repeating third grade this school year for not meeting the state’s reading proficiency standards.
Data released Wednesday by the Indiana Department of Education showed 3.6% of the 84,000 children who took the statewide IREAD exam were retained in third grade under the first enforcement of a requirement approved by the Legislature in 2024.
Those 3,040 retained students is more than seven times the 412 children held back in third grade two years ago.
Education Secretary Katie Jenner credited improved performance by students in the IREAD exam given last school year with the retention figure being lower than anticipated when the literacy requirement was being debated.
“The numbers that were being thrown out is that it would be 7,000 to 10,000 that this law would trigger retention,” Jenner told State Board of Education members. “But, in fact, a huge shout out to our teachers and our people, we have thousands of kids who are now readers.”
Literacy overhaul bill — with third grade retention requirement — heads to Indiana governor

Education officials announced in August that 87.3% of third graders — about 73,500 out of more than 84,000 students statewide — demonstrated proficient reading skills in 2024-25. They hailed the nearly five percentage point improvement from the previous school year as the largest year-to-year jump since the state began IREAD testing in 2013.
That left about 10,600 children who didn’t meet the standard, with almost 7,000 being given “good cause exemptions” to avoid retention. Nearly 75% of those given exemptions were special education students and about 24% are English learners with less than two years of specific literacy services.
Anna Shults, the Department of Education’s chief academic officer, said the new retention requirement was having its intended effect.
“We are now ensuring that students that are promoted on to grade four are doing so with an ability to read and show mastery of key foundational reading skills,” Shults told the State Board of Education.
The Department of Education will have an online dashboard providing breakdowns of the Indiana Reading Evaluation and Determination assessment, or IREAD, by school district and individual schools, including charter schools and nonpublic schools.
Officials noted about 670 children who didn’t meet the literacy standards were not enrolled in Indiana schools this year, saying they likely moved out of state or were being homeschooled.
Jenner said a determination would need to be made about those students if they returned to Indiana schools.
“That’s a question that we’ll need to sort through, because some may move back into Indiana, or if they left for homeschool may come back in,” Jenner said. “Because we’re looking at every unique student, I think we’ll try to figure out exactly where they are.”
According to 2023 data, 13,840 third-graders did not pass I-READ-3. Of those, 5,503 received an exemption and 8,337 did not. Of those without an exemption, 95% moved onto 4th grade while only 412 were retained.

name: South Dakota Searchlight
title: Medical marijuana rift widens as oversight panel confuses and upsets industry with slate of motions
description: The rift between an oversight committee and the state’s medical marijuana industry widened Tuesday in Pierre when the committee approved 11 motions after not making them public before the meeting and not allowing public comment on the individual motions, all while lacking attendance by four of the committee’s 11 members. The intentions of the Medical […]
text:
State Rep. Josephine Garcia, R-Watertown, listens to a presentation during a House Education Committee on Jan. 22, 2025, at the South Dakota Capitol in Pierre. Garcia is the chairwoman of the Medical Marijuana Oversight Committee. (Photo by Makenzie Huber/South Dakota Searchlight)The rift between an oversight committee and the state’s medical marijuana industry widened Tuesday in Pierre when the committee approved 11 motions after not making them public before the meeting and not allowing public comment on the individual motions, all while lacking attendance by four of the committee’s 11 members.
The intentions of the Medical Marijuana Oversight Committee in proposing and approving some of the motions were unclear. The motions were not presented as formal rule change proposals or as bills for the legislative session that starts in January. 
The topics of the motions varied widely and included recommendations for tighter regulations on the medical marijuana industry, tighter regulation of intoxicating products sold outside of the industry in convenience stores and smoke shops, and statements of support or recommendations on an array of other issues.
“My understanding is these are just motions, correct?” said Sen. Lauren Nelson, R-Yankton, a committee member. “So, some of these motions that were approved today will never be heard of again, maybe. Some of these motions might become bills carried by one of us, somebody else that’s in the Legislature, and then we can have our discussion.”
SUBSCRIBE: GET THE MORNING HEADLINES DELIVERED TO YOUR INBOX
Medical marijuana industry lobbyist Jeremiah Murphy asked that the minutes reflect that no advance public notice was given regarding the motions and that no public comment was taken on any of the individual motions. 
“If you want to just call these ‘motions,’ that’s fine,” Murphy said, “But the key is that they not be considered anything like legislation because they were not posted in advance. A bill or resolution must be posted in advance of the hearing.”
The votes capped a combative meeting that was similar in tone to the committee’s prior meeting two weeks ago. That earlier meeting resulted in industry complaints about a day-long slate of invited speakers who presented mostly negative views about marijuana.
Oversight committee testimony sends ‘shock wave’ through SD medical marijuana industry

The committee’s membership consists of four legislators and seven non-legislators, including members from the medical, counseling, law enforcement and patient communities. The absent committee members Tuesday were all non-legislators: Francine Arneson, Kristi Palmer, Andrew Schock and Sioux Falls Police Chief Jon Thum.
At the end of Tuesday’s meeting, the committee took public comment from individuals, capped at two minutes each. 
Kittrick Jeffries, with Puffy’s Dispensary in Rapid City, said the panel was “hashing out issues that the voters decided five years ago.” South Dakota voters legalized medical marijuana in 2020, and the state implemented the program in 2022. There are 17,137 patient cardholders in the state.
“This committee, in my opinion, has only made it harder for patients to access medical cannabis,” Jeffries said. 
Emmett Reistroffer, with Genesis Farms Cannabis Company, called the panel a “show committee” and questioned the motivation of the chairwoman, Rep. Josephine Garcia, R-Watertown, noting she co-sponsored unsuccessful legislation earlier this year to repeal the state’s medical marijuana program. 
“I don’t think you have any business chairing an oversight committee on a program that you publicly opposed in the last legislative session,” Reistroffer said. “Of course, you don’t like what I have to say, but I have two minutes. I am a citizen of the state of South Dakota.”
For that, Garcia muted Reistroffer, but then unmuted him. 
“You can’t mute a member of the public,” Reistroffer said upon being unmuted. He said the action “further cements the fact that this is a show committee.”
Garcia again muted him. 
“The reason that gentleman was gaveled out was for many reasons,” Garcia said. She said he “had things going up online, defaming or whatever he was doing to me.” 
She added, “I believe I’ve been fair, more than fair, and it’s just a disgrace.”
In further public comments, Rep. Travis Ismay, R-Newell, who is not a member of the committee, alleged he saw a state health inspector hug an industry representative outside the room. Ismay was the prime sponsor of the bill to repeal the medical marijuana program that Garcia cosponsored, and he also previously attempted to put an initiative on the ballot to repeal the program. 
“I don’t believe that they’re that trustworthy,” Ismay said of the industry at large.
Department of Health Secretary Melissa Magstadt responded that no Department of Health inspectors were present at the meeting. Ismay returned to the microphone, saying he “might have misspoken or something,” saying he may have misidentified the people he saw. 
Genesis Farms lobbyist Mitch Richter pointed back to the prior committee meeting during which Garcia — a physician — said one of her former patients used artificial intelligence to fake documents, obtain medical marijuana, buy 3 ounces, and sell it for $10,000 a week.
Richter said the allegations don’t “hold water.” 
“If you’re making $10,000 on 3 ounces of marijuana, I want to talk to you,” said Richter, who also said the committee should be repealed. 
Reistroffer later told South Dakota Searchlight that 3 ounces of medical marijuana typically sell for around $600. 
Garcia repeatedly defended the committee and herself, saying the panel stayed within its oversight mandate and the actions taken were “just motions.”
“For those that were disrespectful, shame on you,” she said.
 



 Motions considered

The Medical Marijuana Oversight Committee considered the following motions Tuesday.
Approved

Supporting collaboration with the Department of Health to ensure that noncompliance fines for medical marijuana establishments are fair and equitable, following complaints from the industry that the fines are too high.
Encouraging continued discussion about consistency, inspections and fines and collaboration with the Department of Health.
Recommending that products with THC — the high-inducing compound in marijuana — be banned in stores and THC products be sold only in licensed, medical marijuana facilities.
Recommending that law enforcement have better access to the prescription drug monitoring program or medical marijuana users be required to carry their patient cards at all times.
Supporting legislation requiring closer scrutiny to ensure that patients have a bona fide and continuing relationship with a provider, rather than a one-time relationship based only on obtaining a patient card.
Supporting legislation to ensure that follow-up visits with bona fide physicians may be conducted via telehealth.
Recommending a cap on the THC percentage in products.
Recommending mandatory reporting from the Department of Health regarding hospitalizations, “drug driving,” and poisonings resulting from marijuana use. 
Recommending the Department of Health provide public education on marijuana and medical marijuana.
Supporting the creation of an interim study committee on smoke shops.
Supporting the addition of a pharmacist to the oversight committee (the membership currently includes legislators and non-legislators, with state law requiring membership from the medical, counseling, law enforcement and patient communities).

Failed

Supporting legislation to include a representative of the medical marijuana industry as a member of the committee.

Withdrawn

Requiring warning labels on medical marijuana products (the motion was withdrawn after state officials said such labels are already required).

name: Tennessee Lookout
title: John Cole’s Tennessee: Tax paying blues

name: The Texas Tribune
title: North Texas community votes against forming a city to regulate a noisy Bitcoin mine
description: Some Hood County residents wanted the same power that cities have to set noise limits, but did not secure enough votes.
text: A 24-foot tall wall separates the MARA cryptocurrency facility’s computers from neighboring resident’s homes and land in Hood County on September 24, 2025. Residents on Tuesday voted against incorporating as a city to regulate noise from the facility.

name: Michigan Advance
title: Michigan advocates warn HUD layoffs could weaken housing discrimination enforcement
description: Although the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development’s Region 5 office, which covers Michigan, avoided recent layoffs, fair housing advocates say the cuts elsewhere will still weaken enforcement against housing discrimination nationwide. In mid-October, Reduction in Force notices went out to over 400 HUD employees, including over 100 in the Office o[...]
text:
U.S. Housing and Urban Development Headquarters in Washington, D.C. July 15, 2025. | Photo by Katherine Dailey/Michigan Advance. Although the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development’s Region 5 office, which covers Michigan, avoided recent layoffs, fair housing advocates say the cuts elsewhere will still weaken enforcement against housing discrimination nationwide.
In mid-October, Reduction in Force notices went out to over 400 HUD employees, including over 100 in the Office of Fair Housing and Equal Opportunity, informing them that their positions would no longer exist starting in December. Those notices were primarily in regional HUD offices, with only three offices — Region 2, centered in New York City, Region 5, centered in Chicago, and Region 10, centered in Seattle — avoiding the mass layoffs, according to a statement from the HUD employee union.
Nancy L. Haynes, the executive director of the Fair Housing Center of West Michigan, said that the loss of regional fair housing HUD staff will make it harder — even within regions where the staff still exist — to get issues of housing discrimination resolved.  
“I don’t know how you effectively do fair housing,” Haynes said. “I think now everything will be written up and then sent to headquarters for review, and decisions will all be probably consolidated to come out of headquarters. The groundwork might be done in the regions that remain.”SUPPORT: YOU MAKE OUR WORK POSSIBLE
Beth Romeo, executive director of the Fair Housing Center of Southwest Michigan, noted that the changes coming out of the federal HUD administration worry her in terms of the ability of organizations like hers to receive continued funding from HUD.
“In the case of some of the changes that are coming from D.C., that could impact our ability to process those requests or get responses on those requests from HUD, which essentially then translates into people not getting relief or getting support for their discrimination concerns,” Romeo said. “In many cases, in Southwest Michigan and throughout the state, that can result in people becoming unhoused.”
Haynes, whose organization covers the west side of the state up through the Upper Peninsula, added that she believes that those still at HUD remain committed to the mission — but she does not know how they could handle such an inflated workload. 
“This Administration is completely destroying the federal government’s capacity to address housing discrimination,” added Lisa Rice, the president and CEO of the National Fair Housing Alliance in a press release. 
HUD did not respond to a request for comment. 
Further guidance from John Gibbs, the principal deputy assistant secretary for Fair Housing and Equal Opportunity at HUD, might shed some light on how fair housing enforcement with a smaller workforce might play out. 
Specifically, Gibbs noted in a memo sent to Fair Housing and Equal Opportunity staff that HUD resources should be directed towards “Cases with the Strongest Evidence of Intentional Discrimination.”
The guidance removes “disparate impact” from grounds to take on a housing discrimination case, directing enforcement instead to center on “disparate treatment.” This means that systemic issues like redlining, as well as any issue not falling under the seven federally protected characteristics, will not be eligible to bring to HUD for action. 
Gibbs, who previously served as Ottawa County’s administrator before being fired in Feb. 2024 for “gross misconduct,” argued that the scope of fair housing enforcement had gone too far under prior administrations — “enforcement actions prioritized novel and tenuous theories of discrimination concerned with appraisal bias, environmental justice, local zoning, screening for felony convictions, and gender identity, among others,” the memo wrote.
But Haynes added that this will not have an equal impact on all renters and home buyers. She posed the example of a single occupancy per bedroom policy, which would disproportionately impact a family of four as opposed to a group of four roommates — both groups would require a four-bedroom apartment or home. 
Fair housing enforcement has been on the chopping block for Trump since early in his administration. In February, nearly half of all local fair housing enforcement agencies received notices of cancellation for their funding, totaling around $30 million in cuts. And Trump’s initial budget request, published this spring, asked to cut $60 million from fair housing grants. 
“It definitely seems like fair housing is becoming less of a priority for the administration,” Romeo said. “They’ve made some decisions that really are clear about that position, which is unfortunate, because the need is really there. We get calls every day.”
In Michigan, there were 1,234 total reports of housing discrimination tallied statewide in 2024, according to the National Fair Housing Alliance’s 2025 Fair Housing Trends Report, which was released on Wednesday. 


While that marks a slight decrease, just over 3%, from 2023, the data also shows that certain types of discrimination are on the rise — specifically complaints based on national origin, where Michigan saw one of the largest increases in the country, according to the Fair Housing Trends Report. 
Issues of housing discrimination in Michigan also follow national trends — across the U.S., disability discrimination accounted for over half of the fair housing complaints filed in 2024. Fair housing officials in Michigan noted similar trends. 
“There’s a variety of needs across Southwest Michigan,” Romeo said. “The number one that we see is discrimination against disability, particularly with service animals or emotional support animals.”
As for how to continue forward, fair housing leaders like Haynes and Romeo noted that there are still significant questions on what HUD’s fair housing programs will look like going forward. Answers to those questions are even harder to get during the ongoing federal shutdown, Haynes said, adding that the Michigan Department of Civil Rights has been seeking further clarification from national HUD officials on ongoing guidance. 
“The need and the concerns around discrimination are not going to go away,” Romeo said. “Whatever happens in the next few years, it’s not going to go away. If anything, discrimination is going to increase.”
“We’re trying to figure out how to work together. We already work pretty close,” Haynes added. “Historically, the Michigan fair housing centers have always had a pretty great working relationship. We divide the state up so that we make sure every county even up to the U.P. has a Fair Housing Center. But we’re going to be stretched even thinner.”

name: Iowa Capital Dispatch
title: Appeals court revives lawsuit against city alleging First Amendment retaliation
description: A federal appeals court has reversed, in part, a decision dismissing a lawsuit against the City of West Des Moines alleging First Amendment retaliation and defamation. The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit has reversed a district court’s dismissal of The Conley Group’s claims against the city for First Amendment retaliation and tortious […]
text:
Tom Conley and The Conley Group sued the City of West Des Moines as well as city council members who voted to terminate the city’s contract with the company. (Photo via Getty Images)A federal appeals court has reversed, in part, a decision dismissing a lawsuit against the City of West Des Moines alleging First Amendment retaliation and defamation.
The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit has reversed a district court’s dismissal of The Conley Group’s claims against the city for First Amendment retaliation and tortious interference with a contract, sending the case back to district court. The appellate court affirmed the dismissal of company CEO Tom Conley’s claims for First Amendment retaliation and defamation.
The appeals court also directed the district court to modify its dismissals on Tom Conley’s claims to be without prejudice, clearing the way for those claims to be relitigated.
SUBSCRIBE: GET THE MORNING HEADLINES DELIVERED TO YOUR INBOX
The lawsuit stems from a 2019 decision by the City of West Des Moines to hire The Conley Group, a professional security services company, to provide security for the city through the end of 2021.
In 2020, The Conley Group contracted with the City of Des Moines to provide security at its municipal buildings. Months later, in January 2021, Conley wrote a letter to the editor of the Des Moines Register criticizing a series of articles he felt were unfairly critical of local law enforcement’s response to the unrest that followed the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis, who was murdered by an officer while in police custody.
On July 10, 2021, the Register published a front-page story referring to social media posts and emails in which Tom Conley had likened the actions of the protesters to “terrorism” and referred to the protesters as “thugs” and “snotnosed, punk$$ed, basement dwellers.” The article also indicated Conley had described local Black Lives Matter activists as “nothing but weak, punk—ed little sissy b—— who live in their parents’ basement.”
On Aug. 16, 2021, the West Des Moines City Council voted unanimously to terminate The Conley Group’s security services contract, which was due for renewal at the end of the year. Court records indicate that following the decision, council member Cherry “Renee” Hardman sent a text message to a supporter stating she had used “every ounce” of her political capital “to garner this 5-0 vote,” adding, “We will get sued — but we have decided it is a fight worth fighting.”
Conley’s lawsuit alleges that Hardman then asked the City of Des Moines’ city manager when he was going to “get rid of Conley.” At the time, The Conley Group was in the process of selling a portion of its security business and voluntarily terminated its contract with Des Moines to avoid any negative impact on the transaction.
Tom Conley and The Conley Group then sued the City of West Des Moines as well as Hardman and the four other council members who voted to terminate the city’s contract with the company.
As part of the lawsuit, the plaintiffs alleged the defendants engaged in unconstitutional retaliation for Tom Conley exercising his First Amendment rights when the city canceled its contract in response to his statements. They also alleged the defendants interfered with the company’s business contracts by pressuring Des Moines to cancel its contract with the company, and they alleged the defendants defamed Conley by making statements that branded him a racist.
In a March 2024 order, a district court judge granted the city’s motion to dismiss each count of the lawsuit. That order was based in part on findings that Tom Conley lacked standing to claim damages for injuries to the company; that the only speech that triggered the alleged retaliation was made by Conley and not by the company; and the fact that The Conley Group had voluntarily terminated its contract with the City of Des Moines.
Tom Conley appealed, arguing he had standing to bring a claim for First Amendment retaliation because he had sustained damages through defamation that were independent of those suffered by the company.
With regard to the defamation claim, Conley asserted that the City of West Des Moines and other defendants had “made statements directly and impliedly that Tom Conley was a racist, during city council meetings and in statements that were published to third parties, including the media.”
In dismissing that particular claim, the district court stated that “crucially, (the lawsuit) does not identify any statement made by defendants, much less a series of facially non-libelous statements which allow the audience to ‘connect the dots’ to arrive at a defamatory implication.”
Conley argued “the clear implication” of the city’s actions in canceling his contract “was that Tom Conley was a racist and needed to be punished.”
The district court rejected that argument, finding that Conley was essentially attempting to claim defamation based on the city’s actions rather than on specific statements, which was not the “proper basis for a defamation claim.”
The appeals court agreed, stating that “the only statements identified (in the lawsuit) are articles published by the Des Moines Register, and Conley chose not to sue the newspaper.”

name: Mississippi Today
title: Ocean Springs coughs up hundreds of thousands collected from uninsured motorists
description: Three motorists ticketed in Ocean Springs filed the lawsuit in August 2023 against the Georgia-based company that ran the program, Securix LLC. The city is not a party to the lawsuit, but split revenue 50-50 from the uninsured motorist program with the company.
text:
The city of Ocean Springs plans to place $468,681 into an account linked to a federal lawsuit filed by motorists until a judge decides whether they were improperly ticketed for driving without insurance after traffic cameras captured photos of their license-plates.
The Ocean Springs Board of Aldermen decided Tuesday night to turn the money over to the court, indicating the city is relinquishing any claim to the funds it collected from uninsured motorists.
Three motorists ticketed in Ocean Springs filed the lawsuit in August 2023 against the Georgia-based company that ran the program, Securix LLC. The city is not a party to the lawsuit, but split revenue 50-50 from the uninsured motorist program with the company.
READ MORE: Two Mississippi media companies appeal Supreme Court ruling on sealed court files
The three motorists are seeking class-action status for the lawsuit, filed by Chhabra Gibbs & Herrington of Jackson, so others ticketed in the city also would be represented in the case.
The lawsuit accuses Securix of deceiving vehicle owners by essentially posing as a law enforcement agency through its mailed traffic citations in Ocean Springs.
The city issued a news release after the board voted to relinquish the uninsured motorist fines and fees collected. It said, in part:
“The Southern Poverty Law Center, the MacArthur Justice Center at the University of Mississippi School of Law, Public Justice, and the law firm of Chhabra, Gibbs & Herrington PLLC raised concerns that Securix violated state and federal law and exposed the city to potential financial liability.“Although Ocean Springs contracted with Securix in 2021 with the intent of encouraging uninsured drivers to obtain car insurance, the city later determined that the program did not function as intended and terminated the contract in May 2023.”
How uninsured motorist program worked
The program used automated license plate readers and artificial intelligence to extract license plates that were then run through a database to determine whether the vehicle owner had insurance.
The police department was supposed to review the information and issue the tickets that Securix mailed out.If a vehicle was not listed as being insured, a ticket went to the owner. The system did not identify the person driving the vehicle. On their face, the citations claimed to be uniform traffic tickets that appeared to be from the police department.
READ MORE: Private business ticketed uninsured Mississippi vehicle owners. Then the program blew up.
The Ocean Springs citation offered three options: Call a toll-free number and provide proof of insurance, enter a diversion program that charges a $300 fee and includes a short online course and requires agreement that the vehicle will not be driven uninsured on public roadways, or contest the ticket in court and risk $510 in fines and fees, plus the potential of a one-year driver’s license suspension.
The funds Ocean Springs is turning over to the court represent the city’s share of proceeds collected from motorists.
Securix is in a separate state court battle with three politically connected Mississippians who formed a company called QJR LLC to join the ticketing business.
Jackson area businessmen Josh Gregory and Quinton Dickerson and Pascagoula attorney Robert Wilkinson formed QJR LLC to partner with Securix. They helped spread the program to numerous other Mississippi cities. Gregory and Dickerson own Frontier Strategies, an advertising company that has run campaigns for state and local politicians.
Wilkinson was the city attorney for Ocean Springs when its Securix contract was signed. Wilkinson resigned from the position in June, after the website GCWire.com, published numerous pieces about the ticketing program and his involvement.
QJR is in a bitter legal dispute with Securix and its chairman, Jonathan Miller, in Chancery Court. QJR wants its partnership with Securix dissolved. The partners lost access to the insured motorist database after Miller accused the Mississippians of wrongdoing. The ticketing program no longer operates in Mississippi.
A trial date in the state case is set for January 12 before Judge Neil Harris, whose son, David Harris, is now the city attorney for Ocean Springs.
This article was produced in partnership between the Sun Herald and Mississippi Today.

name: The Texas Tribune
title: “We don’t know what we’re going to eat”: Texans are still waiting for November SNAP benefits
description: Although the federal government has said it will deposit half of November benefits, Texans are still unsure when money will land in their accounts.
text: AJ Wark, 21, a maritime studies student at Texas A&M University at Galveston, poses on campus on Nov. 2, 2025. Wark, who depends on SNAP benefits, said she has had difficulty saving money for essential needs. “A lot of students are able to get a meal plan, but there are students who weren’t approved for loans. Now that SNAP is being cut off, it’s been kind of tough for a lot of us,” she said.

name: Arkansas Advocate
title: Arkansas governor appoints new state insurance commissioner
description: Jimmy Harris is being sworn in Wednesday as the new Arkansas Insurance Commissioner.  Gov. Sarah Huckabee Sanders appointed Harris, who has served as interim commissioner of the Arkansas Insurance Department since August when former commissioner Alan McClain retired.  As commissioner, Harris will lead the Insurance Department, which protects consumers and en[...]
text:
Jimmy Harris was sworn in as the new Arkansas Insurance Commissioner on Nov. 5, 2025. (Photo courtesy of the Arkansas Department of Commerce)Jimmy Harris is being sworn in Wednesday as the new Arkansas Insurance Commissioner. 
Gov. Sarah Huckabee Sanders appointed Harris, who has served as interim commissioner of the Arkansas Insurance Department since August when former commissioner Alan McClain retired. 
As commissioner, Harris will lead the Insurance Department, which protects consumers and ensures the financial stability of insurers, according to an Arkansas Department of Commerce press release. The department also licenses and regulates insurance companies operating in Arkansas, administers the state government’s workers’ compensation program, provides Medicare counseling to senior citizens, and investigates consumer complaints and insurance fraud.
“My top priority as Commissioner is protecting Arkansas consumers and ensuring a fair, stable insurance marketplace…I’m honored to be appointed Commissioner and lead a team so dedicated to serving the people of our state,” Harris said in the release.
Since joining the insurance department in 2012, Harris has held several leadership roles, serving as compliance director and deputy commissioner for market regulation, according to the release. 
“Jimmy’s extensive experience with AID and understanding of its mission make him uniquely equipped to step into this leadership role,” Secretary of Commerce Hugh McDonald said. “Having previously served within the agency, he understands its operations, the industries it regulates, and the consumers it serves.”

name: Nebraska Examiner
title: UNL Faculty Senate to weigh ‘no confidence’ vote against campus chancellor Nov. 18
description: LINCOLN — Faculty at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln are set to consider a “no confidence” vote in Chancellor Rodney Bennett at a Nov. 18 special meeting as Bennett seeks to finalize up to $27.5 million in budget cuts. Elizabeth Lewis, a professor in the Department of Teaching, Learning and Teacher Education, unveiled the emergency motion […]
text:
University of Nebraska-Lincoln Chancellor Rodney Bennett speaks to Nebraska lawmakers on his campus. Dec. 7, 2023. (Zach Wendling/Nebraska Examiner)LINCOLN — Faculty at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln are set to consider a “no confidence” vote in Chancellor Rodney Bennett at a Nov. 18 special meeting as Bennett seeks to finalize up to $27.5 million in budget cuts.
Elizabeth Lewis, a professor in the Department of Teaching, Learning and Teacher Education, unveiled the emergency motion against Bennett at a UNL Faculty Senate meeting Tuesday. The budget cut process is based on a new set of academic program evaluations and data many faculty have questioned.
Lewis, speaking with the Nebraska Examiner on Tuesday night, said the motion is about Bennett’s general service and not just the budget cuts process, though she said faculty concerns about the budget process are “somewhat emblematic of the leadership style that we’ve been experiencing.”
“It’s unfortunate, because you want to have a really strong leader in times like this, and the leadership has not been there,” Lewis said.
A spokesperson for Bennett declined to comment Wednesday on Lewis’ resolution. Bennett’s annual salary is $732,000.
‘Documented failures’ alleged
The draft resolution argues Bennett has “documented failures in strategic leadership, fiscal stewardship, governance integrity, external relations and personnel management.” It calls upon the University of Nebraska Board of Regents and NU President Jeffrey Gold to conduct an “immediate review of the chancellor’s continued fitness to serve.”
Regent Kathy Wilmot of Beaver City, center, is flanked by University of Nebraska-Lincoln Chancellor Rodney Bennett and Mike Zeleny, the former UNL vice chancellor for business and finance. April 26, 2024. (Zach Wendling/Nebraska Examiner)
The regents and Dr. Gold would also be urged to move toward removing Bennett or negotiating his departure, according to the draft resolution. In it, faculty ask for a pause in academic program cuts for an interim appointment and substantial restoration of “shared governance.”
Bennett’s contract allows the regents to terminate his contract with “good cause.” Bennett is allowed to resign if he gives Gold at least 60 days notice.
The NU Board of Regents has not voted whether to extend Bennett’s initial three-year contract. It expires June 30. He came to UNL in July 2023 after nearly a decade as president of the University of Southern Mississippi. He annually dealt with budget cuts at Southern Miss.
Bennett’s leadership has coincided with a string of budget cuts at UNL dating back to June 2020 that, in total, has meant the campus weathering more than $75 million in cuts already. At the same time, the Nebraska Legislature and Gov. Jim Pillen, a former regent for 10 years who became governor in 2023, have slowed state investments in the University of Nebraska.
Will contract be extended?
Bennett, asked by the Examiner in October if or when a regents vote on extending his contract might come, said: “No idea.”
“But I sure hope it comes quickly, because I love being here, love being a part of the community and clearly we have important work yet to do,” Bennett said Oct. 5, after the most recent NU Board of Regents meeting.
Dr. Jeffrey Gold, president of the University of Nebraska system, talks with reporters in the Warner Chamber of the Nebraska State Capitol after giving his first “State of the University” address. Sept. 4, 2025. (Zach Wendling/Nebraska Examiner)
Gold, also speaking with the Examiner after that October meeting, said he would favor extending Bennett’s contract. He said he didn’t know when it might come to a vote — “hopefully sooner than later” — but said regents would decide.
Bennett’s comments mirror what Lewis said she and other faculty have heard from Bennett in Faculty Senate Executive Committee meetings. It also mirrors what a UNL spokesperson said Sept. 12, when Bennett proposed $27.5 million in budget cuts, that Bennett is committed to leading UNL “toward new levels of excellence well into the future.”
Said Lewis: “That’s great, but it’s not enough. It’s not enough just be enthusiastic and say nice things.”
Lewis and other faculty say Bennett should have worked to address UNL’s structural deficit since he started and implemented a strategy. If Bennett desired a metrics-based review of academic programs, faculty say it should have come sooner. Many faculty have said that if given the time, they could have found alternatives to some or all of the suggested academic program cuts.
The latest round of budget cuts proposes eliminating six academic programs. The proposal also would merge four programs and create two interdisciplinary units combining them.
A new budget evaluation model
UNL Executive Vice Chancellor Mark Button, the top campus academic official, has defended UNL’s metrics-based evaluation of its programs. Button in September said the data-based evaluation was “one measure” in addition to a “holistic” qualitative review of all programs.
“We are very mindful that the data can’t tell you everything,” Button said. “It can’t capture all the things that a unit does, and it wasn’t designed to do so.”
Button said the metrics could continue to be an important part of tracking institutional progress.
Faculty from the UNL Department of Educational Administration watch a closed-door hearing into the fate of the department included in the campus chancellor’s plan to trim $27.5 million from UNL’s budget. Selected advocates for the department present a defense of the program area to a committee of faculty, staff and students recommending whether to move forward with the cuts. Oct. 9, 2025. (Zach Wendling/Nebraska Examiner)
A 21-member advisory committee to Bennett of faculty, staff and students has criticized the metrics, the short time frame to finalize budget cuts and the difficulty in finding alternatives. In an unsigned letter, the committee said academic program cuts should be an “absolute last resort,” and some alternatives need months of “concerted efforts to coordinate, not weeks.”
“We are confident that, had they been given time, the campus would have come together to find creative, positive ways to eliminate the structural deficit without proposed program elimination,” the advisory letter states.
Bennett can ultimately take, or leave, the committee’s recommendations. The committee showed majority support in two of the six academic cuts — educational administration and textiles, merchandising and fashion design — albeit narrowly, while urging a pause.
A UNL spokesperson said moving forward with the cuts by the next regents meeting on Dec. 5 is important because “longer delays worsen the university’s cash position.” The advisory group said the university has time, because it might take up to 14 months to actually implement some of the academic cuts.
‘Let’s completely think it out’
John Shrader, president of the UNL Faculty Senate and a professor in sports media and communication, said he hopes all faculty senators take Lewis’ motion back to their respective units and consider how to make it better or suggest other action.
On the motion itself, Shrader said late Tuesday: “I really need to know more.”
“I think we’re in the ‘Let’s completely think it out stage,’” Shrader said.
Shrader said he has felt a “no confidence” vote needs to be the “absolute last resort” and that faculty need to fully think through the process first. He said he feels UNL and the university system have some leadership issues, but he said the Faculty Senate is trying to figure out what it can do to make the situation better.
Lewis, now in her 17th year as faculty, said she is open to changes to her motion and, like Shrader, wanted to give time for faculty to discuss the motion first with peers.
“Yes, there has to be effective institutional management,” Lewis said. “But there also has to be a certain level of duty of care that should be exhibited by the leadership of the university.”
